TEI.2.document_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1922: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1928), 3 vols., Vol 2, pp. 522
TEI.2.document_title: John Austin to Stephen F Austin, 10-24-1830

barker_notes.barker_summary: John Austin to Austin, October 24, 1830. Personal business.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 522

text.body:
*div1 type="summary"* *p*John Austin to Austin, October 24, 1830. Personal business. */p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*[about Ocober 24, 1830.]*/p* *p*I have notified *person_mentioned*Eliza */person_mentioned*of your request and will attend to it, I do not Comprehend the whole affair if I have taken a liberty with the *location_mentioned*place */location_mentioned*to rent it etc. I thot. it yours and done what I believed to be of your interest, I never have received one cent of the rent *person_mentioned*Eliza */person_mentioned*has received it all, I have paid for some repairs making a chimney, etc, If she has complained of me I wish to know it, I never had any other feeling for her than I ought to have had for a *person_mentioned*sister*/person_mentioned* My conduct towards her will prove it in me she found a *person_mentioned*friend */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*protector */person_mentioned*if she complains of a liberty that I have taken with any thing she conceived her property I am astonished for She has taken as many liberties with my things as my wife and has always been welcome— When I see you more can be said on the Subject—*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*J[ohn] A[ustin]*/person_mentioned**/p*
*/div1*
